monogr.title: Alcida : Greenes metamorphosis, vvherein is discouered, a pleasant transformation of bodies into sundrie shapes, shewing that as vertues beautifie the mind, so vanities giue greater staines, than the perfection of any quality can rase out: the discourse confirmed with diuers merry and delightfull histories; full of graue principles to content age, and sawsed with pleasant parlees, and witty answeres, to satisfie youth: profitable for both, and not offensiue to any. By R.G
monogr.author: Greene, Robert

div.head: In praise of the Author.

lg.l: THe busie Bee, that riseth with the Sunne,
Hies forth her hiue, to end her daily taske:
With weary wings she plies into the fields,
And Natures secrets searcheth by her skill,
From flower to flower her carefull way doth flie:
To sucke her hony from her natiue sweet;
Loden, she rich bestirres her to her home,
And there she workes and tilles within her hiue:
Not for her selfe thus busily she romes,
But for vs men, that feed vpon her combes.
So GREENE hath sought into the depth of Art,
With weary labours toyling at his bookes
For fruits, such as the learned Authors yeeld;
Searching the secrets that their wits haue pen'd,
Tossing amongst their learned principles
Their Rhethoricke and deepe Phylosophy:
Gathering the sweet that euery Science giues,
To carry pleasant hony to his hiue.
Not for himselfe alone the Author lookes,
But for such men as daigne to read his bookes.

div.q: Sic vos non vobis melli ficatis apes.
